thread.title: Howell riders second at state equestrian meet
thread.title_full: Howell riders second at state equestrian meet

title: Howell riders second at state equestrian meet
text:
Howell riders second at state equestrian meet Livingston Daily 10:31 p.m. EDT October 19, 2015 The Howell equestrian team poses with the Class B second-place trophy after last weekend's state meet at Midland. The team includes: First row -- (from bottom) Wyatt Barber (holding trophy), Courtney Rajala, Alaina Madison. Second row: Katherine Rajala, Michaela Carnivale, Hannah Frimodig. Third row: Jessica Carsley, Taylor Rajala, Kelsea Goulah. Back row: Coaches Caroline Rajala, Chris Stokes, Brittany Mathes, Cassie Noble. (Photo: Submitted photo) CONNECT 1 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
MIDLAND -- Howell equestrian coach Brittany Mathes knew winning a third consecutive state title was going to be difficult. 
But she was still very pleased that the Highlanders took second in the Class B portion of the Michigan Interscholastic Horsemanship Association meet, which ended Sunday at the Midland County Fairgrounds. 
"It's an honor to be there, and we took a big trophy home still," Mathes said on Monday. "Ten teams were there, and eight went home empty-handed. We are good with it." 
The Highlanders finished second to Grand Haven, 366-345, and nearly 100 points ahead of third-place Oxford. 
"We went to bed Thursday in first place," Mathes said. "On Friday, we were down a point (213-212) and on Saturday we were down 46 points. We knew that if we won every event and they were disqualified in every event, that was the only way we could win." 
The Highlanders had 10 first-place finishes to Grand Haven's nine, and scored 49 points in the flag race. 
The MIHA finals were held in a building that was enclosed on three sides, which meant the wide variety of weather that occurred last weekend was a key player. 
"One of our riders had just finished, and the next rider was out there when hail started hitting the roof," Mathes said. "That horse started going crazy. It sounded like marbles on the roof. It was the luck of the draw. It could have been us." 
It also snowed, rained and sleeted, with temperatures below freezing in the morning all four days. 
"If the weather had been a little better, it might have been a different outcome," Mathes said. 
But she was pleased nonetheless with the 10 firsts. All of the events are scored by two judges, and three riders earned double firsts. Wyatt Barber, a freshman, had two firsts in the flag race, Courtney Rajala had a double first in poles and Taylor Rajala got two firsts in trail riding. 
"We had an awesome show," Mathes said. "Everyone did great, the riders and the coaches." 
In Class A, Hartland finished seventh overall with 124 points, six ahead of eighth-place Milford. In Class C. Fowlerville was eighth with 138 points. 
Soccer 
Pinckney 4, Ypsilanti Lincoln 0 
PINCKNEY -- Tatsu Sakuma had all four goals for the Pirates (2-14-1), who won their district opener on their home field. 
"It's great to get a win, especially in districts," Pirates coach Chris Fowler said. "It was a good team effort. They finally came together. They were so close so many times (to a win), and they put in a quality effort (Monday) and got the result they deserved." 
Riley Alexander had eight saves in net for the Pirates, who play the winner of the Jackson-Ann Arbor Pioneer game at 5 p.m. Wednesday at Ann Arbor Huron. Read or Share this story: http://ldpaa.com/1RTdNC3 TOP VIDEOS
